Appropriations to the medical
department of Johns Hopkins
University totaling $420,000 have
been made during the last few
days by the General Education
- Board of the Rockefeller Foundation.
The first appropriation was an
additional one of $70,000 for the
maintenance of the School of Hygiene and Public Health, which was founded about a year ago.
The second appropriation was
for $350,000, completing the
Board's appropriation of $1,750,000 for full-time service at the
Medical School.
It was announced that the
school would open next October,
but in view of difficulties which
have been encountered as a result
of so many Johns Hopkins doctors being called to service in the
war and the unsettled conditions
generally resulting from the war,
the time of opening is uncertain.
It has been stated at the hospital, however, that plans for the
Hygiene Hospital are now in
shape and in the architect's hands
and that contracts will probably
be given out this summer. The
whole institution and equipment
will cost about $250,000. It will
be located at the southeast corner
of Monument and Wolfe streets.
Of the other $350,000 of the appropriation, $100,000 will go to
the Department of Pediatrics for
full-time work. The remaining
$250,000 is to enable the hospital
to better support the laboratory
subjects, especially the Departments of Pathology, Pharmacology and Physiological Chemistry.
It is explained that the money
will be for endowment only. This
provides for the full-time services
of the medical men, who will suspend their private practices and
devote their full time to hospital
work.
Columbia University has announced one of the most elaborate
programs of extra mural education in its history. Following
out the policy adopted a few
years ago by the Extension
Teaching Department the educational advantages of Columbia
University are now no longer restricted to the university centre
at the campus. Five cities in
which the university will give
courses under its professors with
academic credit where desired,
have been selected by Prof. James
C. Egbert.—Ex..

John C. Knipp & Sons

Nearly one-third of the undergraduates at Hopkins have enlisted in some form of government
service. , Below are given the
branches and' the men enrolled
in each:
U. S. Army (Now at Ft. Myer).

All the energies of the men in
the Hopkins battalion are being
devoted to perfecting the many
phases of drill, in order that the
corps may display itself to a decided advantage in the federal inspection which will be held May
31. Lieutenant Elliott has received word that on this Thursday the Inspector-General of the
Eastern Department of the Army
will examine the battalion and
grade it upon the showing made.
Similar inspections have been
made of the branches of the Reserve Officers' Training Corps ill
other eastern colleges. As it is
doubtful whether the Government
will be able to continue the instruction in military tactics as
it has done this year, except in
those institutions where the training shows itself to be advantageous, the future of the battalion
at Hopkins depends largely upon
the success of Thursday's drill.
As it is assured that neither
Lieutenant Elliott nor his assistants will be back next year, and
as no active officer will be available, Dean Brush is making inquiry for a competent retired officer to take charge of the battalion. Dean Brush says he is
well pleased with the splendid effect the drill has had on the students, and will do everything to
have the instruction continued.
Many members of the faculty, especially Prof. Armstrong who has
been attending drills regularly
since Easter and is now a sergeant, are also desirous that the
training be carried on next fall.
With the resumption of the
fourteen-hour drill program last
Tuesday, preparation for the visit
of the inspector received a decided impetus. The aim at present is principally to perfect the
movements which have already
been studied and guard mounting. Especially close attention is
being paid to the condition of
guns and equipment, and frequent
inspections are held.

The dosing of the college year
will witness the departure of .the
instructors to various parts of
the country. Many will leave at
once for summer homes, but a few
are going to teach in the Johns
Hopkins Summer School before
leaving Baltimore for a rest from
work. Only a few are still undecided as to their plans for the
summer months. The cultivation
of their plots in the faculty gardens is expected to keep several
busy.
President Goodnow will be at
his summer home in Norfolk,
Conn. Dean Brush intends to
spend most of the summer recess
in Rome, N. Y. .Among those who
will remain at Homewood as instructors in the summer school,
which will be under the direction
of Prof. E. F. Buchner, are Dr.
B. T. Baldwin, Dr. H. Slonimsky,
Dr. A. Ember, Dr. J. E. Gilpin,
Dr. R. B. Roulston, Dr. C. L. Powell, Dr. G. Gruenbaum, Dr. C. W.
E. Miller and Dr. R. V. D. Magoffin, who will spend the rest of
the summer at a camp in Canada.
Dr. Roulston and Dr. Powell are
also going to spend a few weeks
on a farm after summer school is
over, and Dr. Powell will complete his vacation up in Canada.
Dr. A. Cohn intends to take his
vacation in Colorado, where, until
the last part of August, he will
teach in the Colorado College
Summer School. Several who are
going north are: Dr. J. E. Shaw,
who will teach in the Columbia
University Summer School, and
Dr. C. Graves is to teach at the
Marine Biological Laboratory at
Woods Hole, Mass., where, in all
probability, Dr. S. 0. Mast will
be also. Prof. H. Wood is going
to his summer home in Northern
Pennsylvania.
Prof. J. H. Latane will spend
his vacation among the mountains
of Virginia, and Dr. W. F. Albright will work on his farm in
the same State. Others who will
pass their vacation in Pennsylvania are Dr. W. F. Shenton and
Dr. J. C. French, who has a summer home at Blue Ridge Summit.
Dr. H. E. Greene, of the English
Department, will be at his home
in Massachusetts this summer.
Among those who will linger in
Baltimore for a large part of the
summer are Dr. W. Rosenau, Dr.
W. Kurrelmeyer, Prof. K. F.
Smith, Dr. E. H. Spieker and
Prof. P. Haupt. Mr. E. Carcassonne will return to France.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 28, 1917.
A Glance Into the Future.

Another college year is passing
into memories, another group of
men receive their sheepskins and
shoulder their responsibilities in
this world of strife, and still the
University continues on its intellectual course through the ages.
We are completing our first year
at Homewood, a year which will
be marked in the annals of the
University as a tremendous step
toward the glorious Homewood of
future days, and in the annals of
the world by the dynamic entrance of the United States into
the colossal struggle for democracy and its transcendent principles.
Two years ago the happiest
dream of the early trustees of
Hopkins was realized when the
new University at Homewood
was dedicated. Last spring its
doors opened to the chattels and
traditions of the old Hopkins,
which had achieved pre-eminence
throughout the intellectual world.
A new era for the University began with magnificent prospects.
Are they -to be dimmed by the
shadow of this conflict? It is the
duty of every Hopkins man to see
that they are not.
But why shudder at the dark,
uncertain future? In the course
of a few years a more blessed
peace than the world has ever
known will reign throughout the
universe. The soldier will go back
to the office, the farm, wherever
duty calls him. The Red Cross
nurse will practice her doctrine
of service in the home. The wheels
of industry will resume their
turning, social bonds will once
more be interwoven. The world
will pass from a hideous night to

a bright, new day. The whole horrible upheaval of the past will
have died as a ripple in the vast
sea of time.
The University will then once
more become a live institution,
throbbing with new blood, pregnant with new possibilities. The
memory of the dreary (144 of wartime will be blotted out by the
sanguine hopes for the future.
The present freshmen may behold
that day. If they remain at the
University through this struggle
they will see Hopkins feel its way
through the fog of today to the
clear radiance of the morrow.
There is no cause for despondent
speculation as to conditions at
Hopkins during the next few
years. The future will take care
of itself, and these trying days
will occupy but a page in the history of our University.
Next fall the University will
start another scholastic year. The
students who come back will have
the regular prescribed work before
them for completion. The excitement and fever of the present hour
will not be an excuse for laxity of
work. The men will be striving
to fit themselves — intellectually,
physically and morally—to cope
with the affairs of the country-the duty of the college man. If
the war continues for several
years they will use their training
to bring it to a successful issue.
If the war ceases they will take
their places in the ranks of our
national servants. At all events,
those who return next fall will
know what lies ahead of them,
an should do all in their power
to Mt themselves for their future
responsibilities and help stabilize
conditions at Hopkins.
Should 8.30 Classes Continue?

The question of having 8.30
classes is again before the students,
and the result of their ,vote will
determinepermanently whether the
present system will be continued
or 9 o'clock classes start again.
Though there are some objections to the present schedule of
hours, such as the number of latenesses, which is inevitable no matter at what hour classes begin, the
inconvenience suffered by two or
three of our suburbanites in catching an earlier train, the conflict
in a few cases of undergraduate
courses with graduate; nevertheless, if daylight practice is to be
had for our football team, the
present arrangement must continue. It seems absurd that a
matter which has been decided
upon once for the *good of college
athletics should be brought up
again. Besides all the objections
are so trivial in comparison with
the benefits of the system. If
Hopkins has teams next year it
must have winning teams, and to
have winning teams it must give
them ample daylight practice.
Our last football season proved
that. The realization of that fact
caused the 8.30 classes to be

started. THE NEWS-LETTER advocated the adoption of the present
system, and, believing it to be
necessary for the good of our
teams and the University, still
approves of it.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY 28, 1917.

FRESHMAN REGULATIONS PASSED
Must Stand Aside for Elders—Wear Black
Socks, Buttons and Caps—Students
to Vote Whether 8.30 Classes
Be Continued.

It will be incumbent upon every
upper-classman to see next year
that the freshmen adhere strictly
to the new regulations made by
the Student Council at a meeting
last Friday at noon, since no
freshie will be permitted to precede a soph, junior or senior in
passing through a door. If one
should be so disrespectful as not
to stand aside at an entrance it
is to be expected that he will
bring the ire of all his elders
down upon his capped head.
Moreover, the initiate to college
life at Hopkins shall wear no
other socks but black, and shall
display a button similar to those
which adorned the present sophomores last year. He shall not
smoke anywhere on the University grounds nor wear his cap in
the buildings, nor enter the Academic Building by any other way
than the basement entrance. The
other rules are about the same as
this year, with the exception of a
new one binding on all except seniors, which says that only they
can use the front entrance of Gilman Hall. All these rules are
binding for one term on every man
just entering Hopkins, who has
not passed through one term at a
similar institution. A man entering the second term (sophomore
year) or above is not subject to
these regulations.
A referendum has been put
to the undergraduates to decide
whether 8.30 A. M. classes will
be continued. The large number
of latenesses and objections from
men living in the suburbs of Baltimore, who find it difficult to
reach the University on time,
caused the Student Council to put
the matter to a vote. Two papers
may be found at the postoffice,
one advocating the continuing of
the present 8.30 classes and the
other asking that the 9 o'clock
class hour of former days be started again. Each student is asked
to sign one or the other at once,
in order that the matter may be
decided Wednesday. The settlement this time will be lasting and
binding all through next year and
1 he Council expects that no opportunity for a change from one
to the other will be offered again.
Tile principle reason for pushing
tile hours up thirty minutes was
to permit football men to have
daylight practice, by giving them
the chance to get out of laboratories at 4.30. As football will
probably be played in the fall the
purpose of the 8.30 classes is still
valid. Tile principal objection on
the part of the faculty is that the
present system conflicts with the
hours set for graduate work.

HULLABALOO TO BE OUT MAY 31;
CONTAINS MANY INNOVATIONS

UNIVERSITY RECEIVES RELICS
OF CHINA AND OF SOUTH SEA

Henry L. Straus, editor-in-chief
of the 1917 Hullabaloo, has announced that the year-book will
be completed and ready for distribution on May 31. The editors have expended much time
and trouble in compiling the material and have introduced a number of innovations which they believe to be improvements over the
distinguishing characteristics of
past Hullabaloos.
The book will be filled with
photographs from cover to cover,
a picture of some sort appearing
on every page. Among these will
be found pictures of the faculty,
of all the college activities and
teams, and of individuals and
groups in- characteristic poses.
Another attractive feature will
be a series of "layouts" on every
member of the class. The weak
points of each 1917 man are to
be exposed unmercifully to the
public, and the editors promise
that none will be spared.

CHANCE FOR ADVANCE STANDING
Hopkins Summer School Offers Advan-

THOMSEN HANDBOOK EDITOR;
STUDENTS TO SOLICIT FOR ADS

At the annual dinner of the
present and next year's Y. M. C.
A. Cabinets and the Advisory
Board on Wednesday, May 9, Roszel C. Thomsen, '19, was elected
editor of the handbook, or "Freshman Bible," for next year. The
soliciting of advertisements will
be carried out by students, thus
saving the Association fifty dollars. All who wish to help in obtaining ads are asked to notify
Mr. Lindley or Mr. Thomsen.
The social service and deputation work, which has been conducted so successfully this year
by the Association, will be continued next fall.
MUSICAL CLUBS ELECT OFFICERS;
MEDALS AWARDED FOR SERVICE

At a recent meeting of the Combined Musical Clubs, Otto Melamet,'19, was elected president for
next year.
W. J. Wells, '18, was elected
treasurer, and L. B. Kellum, '19,
manager. The appointment of the
director and leader of the mandolin club for next year was postponed until the fall.
Gold medals are to be given to
those men who have served on the
clubs for f• our years, and to all
the officers. They are: Spieker,
Bell, Haughton Gorman, Winchester and E. L. Smith.
Those who are to receive silver
medals for three years service are:
Duncan, Strobel, Kauffman, Mela,
met and Owings.
Bronze medals, representing
two years of activity in the clubs,
are to be given to Prince, Wells,
Kellum, A. C. Davis, Shaw, Conn
and Janiver.

STUDIES ENGLISH FAMILY LIFE

DECIDES TO RESUME DEBATING

Dr. Powell Publishes Book on "English
Domestic Relations, 1487-1653"—Attacks Present Conceptions of
Milton's Marriage.

Debating Council Votes for Continuance
of Intercollegiate Triangle Next
Season -Class Trophies to
Adorn Barn.

Dr. Clinton L. Powell's book,
"English Domestic Relations,
1487-1653," which has just been
published, is described on the title
page as "a study of matrimony
and family life as revealed by the
literature, law and history of the
period." Upon examination, the
book proves to be a rather thorough treatise of marriage and divorce from legal and historical
standpoints and of the literature
of domestic relations within the
time named.
The demonstration of a series
of domestic conduct books, as Dr.
Powell says in his preface, "developing front the beginning of
the English Reformation up to the
days of the commonwealth and
running parallel to legal and ecclesiastical agitation in the same
field, is perhaps the most important contribution of the present
study to the history of literature;
but from a wider point of view its
contributions to the history of law
and practice in church and state
as well as its assemblage of legal
and historical material not elsewhere so available may be thought
to be of equal moment."
The preface also calls attention
to two of the appendices to the
book, the first of which presents
the only existing account of the
English writings on the wellknown divorce suit of Henry VIII
and the second attempts to overthrow altogether the present conception of Milton's early married
life and the supposed cause of his
divorce tracts.
For the student of literature
this discussion of Milton's divorce
tracts, with the new theory as to
their cause, forms the most interesting part of the book and offers
a valid raison, d'etre for the
early chapters on the legal status
of marriage and divorce up to
Puritan times. But whether or
not Dr. Powell's contention is
strong enough to overthrow the
long-accepted theory concerning
the writing of these tracts is a
question that will have to be left
for scholars to decide. A further
connection of the general subject
matter of Dr. Powell's study with
the stricter confines of literature
is shown in the possible influence
of the domestic book upon the
more general conduct literature,
upon such moral allegories as
Spenser's "Faerie Queene" and
upon the domestic drama up to
1642.
From the point of view of the
ordinary student, Dr. Powell's
discussion of the English woman
of Elizabethan and Puritan (lays
will probably prove the most
readable portion of the work, but
the whole book, though scholarly
and technical, is not uninterest-

Though the athletic management at the University has under
consideration the usual fall and
spring schedules, the Johns Hopkins-Fifth Regiment track and
field meet and other big events,
the prime object is to get every
student out for some form of athletics. Coach Murphy has said
that he would be glad to have
every man out for football, but if
some are not fitted for that sport,
he has some form of athletic exercise suitable for all. Interclass
Teams in all the sports will probably be organized, and everything
will be done to stimulate interest
in popular sports and to develop
the physical manhood of the student at Hopkins.
One matter which will be settled soon is the conflict of drill
with team practice. President
Goodnow has not yet announced
his plans in regard to that important question, but he is considering it thoroughly. Some new
schedule will probably be arranged whereby all men can take
military training and participate
in athletics too.
Mr. Murphy, in conjunction
with Harry Corner, the graduate
manager, has formulated many
advantageous plans for the undergraduate's physical welfare. He
hopes to have every man active in
some sport and all co-operating
with him in turning out fast
teams, playing clean games.

"We Must Make Good."
To the Editor of TIIE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—This time of the year is
rich with memories of Hopkins in
peace times—the annual decoration of the Trophy Room with brilliant championship banners and
shining trophies brought home by
the spring teams, the impatient
anticipation of the festivities of
Senior Week, and (to recall the
painful, as well as the pleasant)
the cramming and the fearing and
the general panicky feeling on the
eve of final examinations. This
year everything is different. Now
even such supposedly eternal institutions as examinations have
been sacrificed for the grimn work
of war.
The only offering that we can,
at the close. of this year, lay in the
lap of our Alma gater is "efficiency in military training."
Revolutionary and ridiculous as
that may pound, we are proud to
admit that it is true. The stake
of the military inspection next

week is nothing less than the honor
of the University. The loyalty and
love of us, who are not yet in the
active service of our country, for
our University will be ,placed in
the balance. We must make good.
We must put all the pep and the
life and the fight that would have
been spent in lacrosse and ball
games into these last drills. We
must show the faculty that they
were justified in their recent action
and that we are in full sympathy
with the motives that prompted
their action. We must pay our
debt of gratitude and apprecia—
tion to the "fighting men of our
faculty"—Lieutenant Elliott, Sergeant Friedlander and Sergeant
Evans—whose efforts deserve the
very best that we can give: Hopkins never has known failure
(obstacles and handicaps notwithstanding), and, if we can help it,
MoNrrus.
she never will.
May 24, 1917.

Novel Form of Election Tried.

When Firor was elected captain
of next year's track team a novel
scheme of voting was put into
practice and proved very successful. The Athletic Board held a
meeting. and nominated several
men whom they considered capable of leading the team. These
nominations were then mailed to
the various eligible voters of the
squad and the votes received in a
short time by return mail. All
confusion as to eligible voters was
voided and the complications of
unnecessary nominations was done
away with. Capt. Harry Straus
of this year's team recommended
the new system as a possible
means of simplifying future elections among all the. different
branches of athletics.

Shoots Highest in City League—To Meet
B. A. C. Team for Championship
of Baltimore — Improved
Range Next Year.

The Johns Hopkins Rifle Club
has made an extraordinarily good
showing during the past year. Of
the fourteen matches in which
the team participated, it lost but
one. Last October the Rifle Club joined a city league of eight
teams, and at the close of the
league season came out victorious.
On Monday, May 28, the Johns
Hopkins team meets that of the
Baltimore Athletic Club, the leader of another city league, in a
match for the championship of
Baltimore. This match, to be
held at the new range in the old
Hopkins gymnasium, will probably be the last of the year for
Johns Hopkins.
The Club had an enrollment of
forty-five members some time ago,
but the ranks are much depleted
by the departure of many active
members for training camps or
farms. Hence, the Club will need
men greatly next year, when it
expects, if war does not prevent,
to compete in intercollegiate
matches. The rifle team will also
continue in the city league, and
will have improved range facilities.

Appropriations to the medical
department of Johns Hopkins
University totaling $420,000 have
been made during the last few
days by the General Education
- Board of the Rockefeller Foundation.
The first appropriation was an
additional one of $70,000 for the
maintenance of the School of Hygiene and Public Health, which was founded about a year ago.
The second appropriation was
for $350,000, completing the
Board's appropriation of $1,750,000 for full-time service at the
Medical School.
It was announced that the
school would open next October,
but in view of difficulties which
have been encountered as a result
of so many Johns Hopkins doctors being called to service in the
war and the unsettled conditions
generally resulting from the war,
the time of opening is uncertain.
It has been stated at the hospital, however, that plans for the
Hygiene Hospital are now in
shape and in the architect's hands
and that contracts will probably
be given out this summer. The
whole institution and equipment
will cost about $250,000. It will
be located at the southeast corner
of Monument and Wolfe streets.
Of the other $350,000 of the appropriation, $100,000 will go to
the Department of Pediatrics for
full-time work. The remaining
$250,000 is to enable the hospital
to better support the laboratory
subjects, especially the Departments of Pathology, Pharmacology and Physiological Chemistry.
It is explained that the money
will be for endowment only. This
provides for the full-time services
of the medical men, who will suspend their private practices and
devote their full time to hospital
work.
Columbia University has announced one of the most elaborate
programs of extra mural education in its history. Following
out the policy adopted a few
years ago by the Extension
Teaching Department the educational advantages of Columbia
University are now no longer restricted to the university centre
at the campus. Five cities in
which the university will give
courses under its professors with
academic credit where desired,
have been selected by Prof. James
C. Egbert.—Ex..

Nearly one-third of the undergraduates at Hopkins have enlisted in some form of government
service. , Below are given the
branches and' the men enrolled
in each:
U. S. Army (Now at Ft. Myer).

All the energies of the men in
the Hopkins battalion are being
devoted to perfecting the many
phases of drill, in order that the
corps may display itself to a decided advantage in the federal inspection which will be held May
31. Lieutenant Elliott has received word that on this Thursday the Inspector-General of the
Eastern Department of the Army
will examine the battalion and
grade it upon the showing made.
Similar inspections have been
made of the branches of the Reserve Officers' Training Corps ill
other eastern colleges. As it is
doubtful whether the Government
will be able to continue the instruction in military tactics as
it has done this year, except in
those institutions where the training shows itself to be advantageous, the future of the battalion
at Hopkins depends largely upon
the success of Thursday's drill.
As it is assured that neither
Lieutenant Elliott nor his assistants will be back next year, and
as no active officer will be available, Dean Brush is making inquiry for a competent retired officer to take charge of the battalion. Dean Brush says he is
well pleased with the splendid effect the drill has had on the students, and will do everything to
have the instruction continued.
Many members of the faculty, especially Prof. Armstrong who has
been attending drills regularly
since Easter and is now a sergeant, are also desirous that the
training be carried on next fall.
With the resumption of the
fourteen-hour drill program last
Tuesday, preparation for the visit
of the inspector received a decided impetus. The aim at present is principally to perfect the
movements which have already
been studied and guard mounting. Especially close attention is
being paid to the condition of
guns and equipment, and frequent
inspections are held.

The dosing of the college year
will witness the departure of .the
instructors to various parts of
the country. Many will leave at
once for summer homes, but a few
are going to teach in the Johns
Hopkins Summer School before
leaving Baltimore for a rest from
work. Only a few are still undecided as to their plans for the
summer months. The cultivation
of their plots in the faculty gardens is expected to keep several
busy.
President Goodnow will be at
his summer home in Norfolk,
Conn. Dean Brush intends to
spend most of the summer recess
in Rome, N. Y. .Among those who
will remain at Homewood as instructors in the summer school,
which will be under the direction
of Prof. E. F. Buchner, are Dr.
B. T. Baldwin, Dr. H. Slonimsky,
Dr. A. Ember, Dr. J. E. Gilpin,
Dr. R. B. Roulston, Dr. C. L. Powell, Dr. G. Gruenbaum, Dr. C. W.
E. Miller and Dr. R. V. D. Magoffin, who will spend the rest of
the summer at a camp in Canada.
Dr. Roulston and Dr. Powell are
also going to spend a few weeks
on a farm after summer school is
over, and Dr. Powell will complete his vacation up in Canada.
Dr. A. Cohn intends to take his
vacation in Colorado, where, until
the last part of August, he will
teach in the Colorado College
Summer School. Several who are
going north are: Dr. J. E. Shaw,
who will teach in the Columbia
University Summer School, and
Dr. C. Graves is to teach at the
Marine Biological Laboratory at
Woods Hole, Mass., where, in all
probability, Dr. S. 0. Mast will
be also. Prof. H. Wood is going
to his summer home in Northern
Pennsylvania.
Prof. J. H. Latane will spend
his vacation among the mountains
of Virginia, and Dr. W. F. Albright will work on his farm in
the same State. Others who will
pass their vacation in Pennsylvania are Dr. W. F. Shenton and
Dr. J. C. French, who has a summer home at Blue Ridge Summit.
Dr. H. E. Greene, of the English
Department, will be at his home
in Massachusetts this summer.
Among those who will linger in
Baltimore for a large part of the
summer are Dr. W. Rosenau, Dr.
W. Kurrelmeyer, Prof. K. F.
Smith, Dr. E. H. Spieker and
Prof. P. Haupt. Mr. E. Carcassonne will return to France.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 28, 1917.
A Glance Into the Future.

Another college year is passing
into memories, another group of
men receive their sheepskins and
shoulder their responsibilities in
this world of strife, and still the
University continues on its intellectual course through the ages.
We are completing our first year
at Homewood, a year which will
be marked in the annals of the
University as a tremendous step
toward the glorious Homewood of
future days, and in the annals of
the world by the dynamic entrance of the United States into
the colossal struggle for democracy and its transcendent principles.
Two years ago the happiest
dream of the early trustees of
Hopkins was realized when the
new University at Homewood
was dedicated. Last spring its
doors opened to the chattels and
traditions of the old Hopkins,
which had achieved pre-eminence
throughout the intellectual world.
A new era for the University began with magnificent prospects.
Are they -to be dimmed by the
shadow of this conflict? It is the
duty of every Hopkins man to see
that they are not.
But why shudder at the dark,
uncertain future? In the course
of a few years a more blessed
peace than the world has ever
known will reign throughout the
universe. The soldier will go back
to the office, the farm, wherever
duty calls him. The Red Cross
nurse will practice her doctrine
of service in the home. The wheels
of industry will resume their
turning, social bonds will once
more be interwoven. The world
will pass from a hideous night to

a bright, new day. The whole horrible upheaval of the past will
have died as a ripple in the vast
sea of time.
The University will then once
more become a live institution,
throbbing with new blood, pregnant with new possibilities. The
memory of the dreary (144 of wartime will be blotted out by the
sanguine hopes for the future.
The present freshmen may behold
that day. If they remain at the
University through this struggle
they will see Hopkins feel its way
through the fog of today to the
clear radiance of the morrow.
There is no cause for despondent
speculation as to conditions at
Hopkins during the next few
years. The future will take care
of itself, and these trying days
will occupy but a page in the history of our University.
Next fall the University will
start another scholastic year. The
students who come back will have
the regular prescribed work before
them for completion. The excitement and fever of the present hour
will not be an excuse for laxity of
work. The men will be striving
to fit themselves — intellectually,
physically and morally—to cope
with the affairs of the country-the duty of the college man. If
the war continues for several
years they will use their training
to bring it to a successful issue.
If the war ceases they will take
their places in the ranks of our
national servants. At all events,
those who return next fall will
know what lies ahead of them,
an should do all in their power
to Mt themselves for their future
responsibilities and help stabilize
conditions at Hopkins.
Should 8.30 Classes Continue?

The question of having 8.30
classes is again before the students,
and the result of their ,vote will
determinepermanently whether the
present system will be continued
or 9 o'clock classes start again.
Though there are some objections to the present schedule of
hours, such as the number of latenesses, which is inevitable no matter at what hour classes begin, the
inconvenience suffered by two or
three of our suburbanites in catching an earlier train, the conflict
in a few cases of undergraduate
courses with graduate; nevertheless, if daylight practice is to be
had for our football team, the
present arrangement must continue. It seems absurd that a
matter which has been decided
upon once for the *good of college
athletics should be brought up
again. Besides all the objections
are so trivial in comparison with
the benefits of the system. If
Hopkins has teams next year it
must have winning teams, and to
have winning teams it must give
them ample daylight practice.
Our last football season proved
that. The realization of that fact
caused the 8.30 classes to be

started. THE NEWS-LETTER advocated the adoption of the present
system, and, believing it to be
necessary for the good of our
teams and the University, still
approves of it.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY 28, 1917.

FRESHMAN REGULATIONS PASSED
Must Stand Aside for Elders—Wear Black
Socks, Buttons and Caps—Students
to Vote Whether 8.30 Classes
Be Continued.

It will be incumbent upon every
upper-classman to see next year
that the freshmen adhere strictly
to the new regulations made by
the Student Council at a meeting
last Friday at noon, since no
freshie will be permitted to precede a soph, junior or senior in
passing through a door. If one
should be so disrespectful as not
to stand aside at an entrance it
is to be expected that he will
bring the ire of all his elders
down upon his capped head.
Moreover, the initiate to college
life at Hopkins shall wear no
other socks but black, and shall
display a button similar to those
which adorned the present sophomores last year. He shall not
smoke anywhere on the University grounds nor wear his cap in
the buildings, nor enter the Academic Building by any other way
than the basement entrance. The
other rules are about the same as
this year, with the exception of a
new one binding on all except seniors, which says that only they
can use the front entrance of Gilman Hall. All these rules are
binding for one term on every man
just entering Hopkins, who has
not passed through one term at a
similar institution. A man entering the second term (sophomore
year) or above is not subject to
these regulations.
A referendum has been put
to the undergraduates to decide
whether 8.30 A. M. classes will
be continued. The large number
of latenesses and objections from
men living in the suburbs of Baltimore, who find it difficult to
reach the University on time,
caused the Student Council to put
the matter to a vote. Two papers
may be found at the postoffice,
one advocating the continuing of
the present 8.30 classes and the
other asking that the 9 o'clock
class hour of former days be started again. Each student is asked
to sign one or the other at once,
in order that the matter may be
decided Wednesday. The settlement this time will be lasting and
binding all through next year and
1 he Council expects that no opportunity for a change from one
to the other will be offered again.
Tile principle reason for pushing
tile hours up thirty minutes was
to permit football men to have
daylight practice, by giving them
the chance to get out of laboratories at 4.30. As football will
probably be played in the fall the
purpose of the 8.30 classes is still
valid. Tile principal objection on
the part of the faculty is that the
present system conflicts with the
hours set for graduate work.

HULLABALOO TO BE OUT MAY 31;
CONTAINS MANY INNOVATIONS

UNIVERSITY RECEIVES RELICS
OF CHINA AND OF SOUTH SEA

Henry L. Straus, editor-in-chief
of the 1917 Hullabaloo, has announced that the year-book will
be completed and ready for distribution on May 31. The editors have expended much time
and trouble in compiling the material and have introduced a number of innovations which they believe to be improvements over the
distinguishing characteristics of
past Hullabaloos.
The book will be filled with
photographs from cover to cover,
a picture of some sort appearing
on every page. Among these will
be found pictures of the faculty,
of all the college activities and
teams, and of individuals and
groups in- characteristic poses.
Another attractive feature will
be a series of "layouts" on every
member of the class. The weak
points of each 1917 man are to
be exposed unmercifully to the
public, and the editors promise
that none will be spared.

CHANCE FOR ADVANCE STANDING
Hopkins Summer School Offers Advan-

THOMSEN HANDBOOK EDITOR;
STUDENTS TO SOLICIT FOR ADS

At the annual dinner of the
present and next year's Y. M. C.
A. Cabinets and the Advisory
Board on Wednesday, May 9, Roszel C. Thomsen, '19, was elected
editor of the handbook, or "Freshman Bible," for next year. The
soliciting of advertisements will
be carried out by students, thus
saving the Association fifty dollars. All who wish to help in obtaining ads are asked to notify
Mr. Lindley or Mr. Thomsen.
The social service and deputation work, which has been conducted so successfully this year
by the Association, will be continued next fall.
MUSICAL CLUBS ELECT OFFICERS;
MEDALS AWARDED FOR SERVICE

At a recent meeting of the Combined Musical Clubs, Otto Melamet,'19, was elected president for
next year.
W. J. Wells, '18, was elected
treasurer, and L. B. Kellum, '19,
manager. The appointment of the
director and leader of the mandolin club for next year was postponed until the fall.
Gold medals are to be given to
those men who have served on the
clubs for f• our years, and to all
the officers. They are: Spieker,
Bell, Haughton Gorman, Winchester and E. L. Smith.
Those who are to receive silver
medals for three years service are:
Duncan, Strobel, Kauffman, Mela,
met and Owings.
Bronze medals, representing
two years of activity in the clubs,
are to be given to Prince, Wells,
Kellum, A. C. Davis, Shaw, Conn
and Janiver.

STUDIES ENGLISH FAMILY LIFE

DECIDES TO RESUME DEBATING

Dr. Powell Publishes Book on "English
Domestic Relations, 1487-1653"—Attacks Present Conceptions of
Milton's Marriage.

Debating Council Votes for Continuance
of Intercollegiate Triangle Next
Season -Class Trophies to
Adorn Barn.

Dr. Clinton L. Powell's book,
"English Domestic Relations,
1487-1653," which has just been
published, is described on the title
page as "a study of matrimony
and family life as revealed by the
literature, law and history of the
period." Upon examination, the
book proves to be a rather thorough treatise of marriage and divorce from legal and historical
standpoints and of the literature
of domestic relations within the
time named.
The demonstration of a series
of domestic conduct books, as Dr.
Powell says in his preface, "developing front the beginning of
the English Reformation up to the
days of the commonwealth and
running parallel to legal and ecclesiastical agitation in the same
field, is perhaps the most important contribution of the present
study to the history of literature;
but from a wider point of view its
contributions to the history of law
and practice in church and state
as well as its assemblage of legal
and historical material not elsewhere so available may be thought
to be of equal moment."
The preface also calls attention
to two of the appendices to the
book, the first of which presents
the only existing account of the
English writings on the wellknown divorce suit of Henry VIII
and the second attempts to overthrow altogether the present conception of Milton's early married
life and the supposed cause of his
divorce tracts.
For the student of literature
this discussion of Milton's divorce
tracts, with the new theory as to
their cause, forms the most interesting part of the book and offers
a valid raison, d'etre for the
early chapters on the legal status
of marriage and divorce up to
Puritan times. But whether or
not Dr. Powell's contention is
strong enough to overthrow the
long-accepted theory concerning
the writing of these tracts is a
question that will have to be left
for scholars to decide. A further
connection of the general subject
matter of Dr. Powell's study with
the stricter confines of literature
is shown in the possible influence
of the domestic book upon the
more general conduct literature,
upon such moral allegories as
Spenser's "Faerie Queene" and
upon the domestic drama up to
1642.
From the point of view of the
ordinary student, Dr. Powell's
discussion of the English woman
of Elizabethan and Puritan (lays
will probably prove the most
readable portion of the work, but
the whole book, though scholarly
and technical, is not uninterest-

Though the athletic management at the University has under
consideration the usual fall and
spring schedules, the Johns Hopkins-Fifth Regiment track and
field meet and other big events,
the prime object is to get every
student out for some form of athletics. Coach Murphy has said
that he would be glad to have
every man out for football, but if
some are not fitted for that sport,
he has some form of athletic exercise suitable for all. Interclass
Teams in all the sports will probably be organized, and everything
will be done to stimulate interest
in popular sports and to develop
the physical manhood of the student at Hopkins.
One matter which will be settled soon is the conflict of drill
with team practice. President
Goodnow has not yet announced
his plans in regard to that important question, but he is considering it thoroughly. Some new
schedule will probably be arranged whereby all men can take
military training and participate
in athletics too.
Mr. Murphy, in conjunction
with Harry Corner, the graduate
manager, has formulated many
advantageous plans for the undergraduate's physical welfare. He
hopes to have every man active in
some sport and all co-operating
with him in turning out fast
teams, playing clean games.

The functions of the Advisory
Committee at Hopkins will be
mainly to insure the solidarity of
the league, to supervise the arranging of schedules in interscholastic sports and to stimulate
interest in them, to plan big athletic carnivals and meets, which
will probably be held at Homewood, and to give advice on all
important questions which may
arise. It is expected that by next
fall Mr. Kistler will have made
the proposed league a reality, as
his plans are already formulated,
and it is almost assured that
every preparatory school in Baltimore is eager to be admitted
into such an organization.'

"We Must Make Good."
To the Editor of TIIE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—This time of the year is
rich with memories of Hopkins in
peace times—the annual decoration of the Trophy Room with brilliant championship banners and
shining trophies brought home by
the spring teams, the impatient
anticipation of the festivities of
Senior Week, and (to recall the
painful, as well as the pleasant)
the cramming and the fearing and
the general panicky feeling on the
eve of final examinations. This
year everything is different. Now
even such supposedly eternal institutions as examinations have
been sacrificed for the grimn work
of war.
The only offering that we can,
at the close. of this year, lay in the
lap of our Alma gater is "efficiency in military training."
Revolutionary and ridiculous as
that may pound, we are proud to
admit that it is true. The stake
of the military inspection next

week is nothing less than the honor
of the University. The loyalty and
love of us, who are not yet in the
active service of our country, for

Novel Form of Election Tried.

When Firor was elected captain
of next year's track team a novel
scheme of voting was put into
practice and proved very successful. The Athletic Board held a
meeting. and nominated several
men whom they considered capable of leading the team. These
nominations were then mailed to
the various eligible voters of the
squad and the votes received in a
short time by return mail. All
confusion as to eligible voters was
voided and the complications of
unnecessary nominations was done
away with. Capt. Harry Straus
of this year's team recommended
the new system as a possible
means of simplifying future elections among all the. different
branches of athletics.

Shoots Highest in City League—To Meet
B. A. C. Team for Championship
of Baltimore — Improved
Range Next Year.

The Johns Hopkins Rifle Club
has made an extraordinarily good
showing during the past year. Of
the fourteen matches in which
the team participated, it lost but
one. Last October the Rifle Club joined a city league of eight
teams, and at the close of the
league season came out victorious.
On Monday, May 28, the Johns
Hopkins team meets that of the
Baltimore Athletic Club, the leader of another city league, in a
match for the championship of
Baltimore. This match, to be
held at the new range in the old
Hopkins gymnasium, will probably be the last of the year for
Johns Hopkins.
The Club had an enrollment of
forty-five members some time ago,
but the ranks are much depleted
by the departure of many active
members for training camps or
farms. Hence, the Club will need
men greatly next year, when it
expects, if war does not prevent,
to compete in intercollegiate
matches. The rifle team will also
continue in the city league, and
will have improved range facilities.
